tit.cmt: このファイルの用語については、同神社のホームページを参考にしたhttp://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/yasaka/english/index.html

sen.j: 八坂神社（やさかじんじゃ）は、素戔嗚尊（スサノオ）を祭神とする全国各地にある神社の名称。
sen.e: Yasaka-jinja Shrine is the name for Shinto shrines all around the country that enshrine the deity Susanoo-no-mikoto.
Yasaka-jinja Shrine is the name for Shinto shrines all around the country that enshrine the deity Susanoo-no-mikoto.
Yasaka-jinja Shrine is the name for Shinto shrines all around the country that enshrine the deity Susanoo-no-mikoto.

sen.j: 日本全国に約2300社あるとされる。
sen.e: There are about 2300 in all of Japan.
There are about 2300 in all of Japan.
There are about 2300 in all of Japan.

sen.j: 総本社は京都府京都市東山区祇園町にある八坂神社。
sen.e: The central shrine over all of them is Yasaka-jinja Shrine in Gion-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto.
The Central Shrine over all of them is Yasaka-jinja Shrine in Gion-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 総本社の頭文字を大文字に。
sen.e: The Central Shrine over all of them is Yasaka-jinja Shrine in Gion-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto.

sen.j: かつての社名から祇園さんの愛称で呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is called by the nickname Gion-san, from the old name for the shrine.
It is called by the nickname Gion-san, from the old name for the shrine.
It is called by the nickname Gion-san, from the old name for the shrine.

sen.j: 7月の祇園祭で知られ、ほかに特殊神事として白朮（をけら）祭がある。
sen.e: Known for the Gion Festival in July, it also has a special event called Okera-sai.
Known for the Gion Festival in July, and it also has a special Shinto ritual called Okera-sai.
Known for the Gion Festival in July, and it also has a special Shinto ritual called Okera-sai.

sen.j: 旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: Under the old Shakaku system, it was a Kanpei Taisha.
Under the old Shakaku system, it was a Kanpei Taisha.
Under the old Shakaku system, it was a Kanpei Taisha.

sen.j: 明治元年の神仏分離令（廃仏毀釈運動）により、元々「祇園社」「祇園感神院」と呼ばれていたのが「八坂神社」と改められた。
sen.e: Under the Separation Orders (anti-Buddhist movement) in the first year of Meiji, what was originally called Gion-sha/Gion Kanshin-in was changed to Yasaka Jinja.
sen.cmt: 神仏分離令の訳としては他にLaw Separating Shinto and Buddhism、Order for the separation of Buddhas and kamiなどもみられるが、定訳不明
sen.e: Under the Separation Orders (anti-Buddhist movement) in the first year of Meiji, what was originally called Gion-sha/Gion Kanshin-in was changed to Yasaka-jinja Shrine.
Under the Separation Orders (anti-Buddhist movement) in the first year of Meiji, what was originally called Gion-sha/Gion Kanshin-in was changed to Yasaka-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 中間 -- スサノオ（スサノヲノミコト）
sen.e: Naka-no-ma - Susanoo (Susanoo-no-mikoto)
Naka-no-ma - Susanoo (Susanoo-no-mikoto)

sen.j: となっているが、明治時代の神仏判然令以前の御祭神は、
sen.e: But before the Shinbutsu Hanzen Order in the Meiji period they were:

sen.j: 中の座 -- 牛頭天王（ゴズテンノウ）
sen.e: Naka-no-za - Gozu Tenno
Naka-no-za - Gozu-Tennou
Naka-no-za - Gozu-Tennou

sen.j: 東の座 -- 沙竭羅竜王（サガラリュウオウ）
sen.e: Higashi-no-za - Sagara Ryuo
Higashi-no-za - Sagara-ryuo
Higashi-no-za - Sagara-ryuo

sen.j: 西の座 -- 頗梨采女（ハリサイニョ（ウネメ））
sen.e: Nishi-no-za - Harisainyo(uneme)
Nishi-no-za - Harisainyo(uneme)
Nishi-no-za - Harisainyo(uneme)

sen.j: 牛頭天王は仏教の守護神で、日本では素戔嗚尊と同神とされていた。
sen.e: Gozu Tenno is a guardian deity of Buddhism, and is considered to be the same god as Susanoo-no-mikoto in Japan.
Gozu-Tennou is a guardian deity of Buddhism, and is considered to be the same god as Susanoo-no-mikoto in Japan.
Gozu-Tennou is a guardian deity of Buddhism, and is considered to be the same god as Susanoo-no-mikoto in Japan.

sen.j: 頗梨采女はその妻で、沙竭羅竜王は頗梨采女の父である。
sen.e: Harisainyo is his wife, whose father is Sagara Ryuo.
Harisainyo is his wife, whose father is Sagara-ryuo.
Harisainyo is his wife, whose father is Sagara-ryuo.

sen.j: 牛頭天王は祇園精舎を守護するとされていた。
sen.e: Gozu Tenno is said to protect Gion Shoja.
Gozu-Tennou is said to protect Gion Shoja.
sen.cmt: 定訳に合わせた。 精舎は、Shoja の方がより一般的なようなので、このままで可。
sen.e: Gozu-Tennou is said to protect Gion Shoja.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: （写真）東山花灯路の頃の八坂神社
sen.e: (Picture) Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the time of the Higashiyama Flower Lanterns
(Picture) Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the time of the Higashiyama Flower Lanterns
(Picture) Yasaka-jinja Shrine at the time of the Higashiyama Flower Lanterns

sen.j: 社伝によれば、斉明天皇2年（656年）、高句麗より来日した調進副使・伊利之使主（いりしおみ）が、新羅の牛頭山に祀られる素戔嗚尊を山城国愛宕郡八坂郷に祀り、「八坂造」の姓を賜ったのに始まるという。
sen.e: According to shrine records, it began in 656 when Choshin Fukushi/Irishiomi from Koguryo enshrined Susanoo-no-mikoto, who is enshrined at Mt. Gozu in Shilla, at Yasakago in Otagi-gun, Yamashiro province, and received the name "Yasaka-no-Miyatsuko".
sen.cmt: 調進副使、伊利之使主、表記不明愛宕郡の読み方は以下参照。http://heiankyoyashiro.blog116.fc2.com/blog-date-200806.htmlhttp://tabisuke.arukikata.co.jp/ds/r/207/r/20026/r/20704/9/DomesticSpot/13999/p/1/八坂郷の読み方は以下参照。http://www.city.kyoto.jp/somu/rekishi/fm/nenpyou/htmlsheet/bunka01.htmlhttp://www.city.kyoto.jp/somu/rekishi/fm/nenpyou/htmlsheet/toshi09.html
sen.e: According to shrine records, it began in 656 when Choshin Fukushi/Irishiomi from Koguryo enshrined Susanoo-no-mikoto, who is enshrined at Mt. Gozu in Shilla, at Yasakago in Otagi-gun, Yamashiro province, and received the name "Yasaka-no-Miyatsuko".

According to shrine records, it began in 656 when Choshin Fukushi/Irishiomi from Koguryo enshrined Susanoo-no-mikoto, who is enshrined at Mt. Gozu in Shilla, at Yasakago in Otagi-gun, Yamashiro province, and received the name "Yasaka-no-Miyatsuko".

sen.j: 他にも各種の記録がある。
sen.e: There are various other records, as well.
There are various other records, as well.
There are various other records, as well.

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)18年（876年）に僧・円如が播磨国広峯神社の牛頭天王の分霊を遷し、その後、藤原基経が精舎を建立して観慶寺（別名 祇園寺）と称した
sen.e: In 876 a monk named Ennyo transferred a piece of Gozu Tenno's spirit from Hiromine Shrine in Harima province; later Mototsune FUJIWARA built the Shoja and called it Kankei-ji temple (aka Gion-ji temple).

In 876 a monk named Ennyo transferred a piece of Gozu -Tennou's spirit from Hiromine Shrine in Harima province; later Mototsune FUJIWARA built the Shoja and called it Kankei-ji temple (aka Gion-ji temple).

In 876 a monk named Ennyo transferred a piece of Gozu -Tennou's spirit from Hiromine Shrine in Harima province; later Mototsune FUJIWARA built the Shoja and called it Kankei-ji temple (aka Gion-ji temple).

sen.j: 延長 (元号)4年（926年）、ある修行僧が祇園天神堂を建てた
sen.e: In 926 a monk built Gion Tenjindo.
sen.cmt: 祇園天神堂の表記、以下参照http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=3xCmj2jJFTYC&pg=RA1-PA25&lpg=RA1-PA25&dq=%22gion+tenjindo%22&source=bl&ots=wqNRqvA6Fw&sig=QWDauYU2cRneIv-Sd34liiPKSgw&hl=ja&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result
sen.e: In 926 a monk built Gion Tenjindo.
In 926 a monk built Gion Tenjindo.

sen.j: 承平 (日本)4年（934年）に祇園感神院を建てた
sen.e: In 934 he built Gion Kanshin-in.
In 934 he built Gion Kanshin-in.
In 934 he built Gion Kanshin-in.

sen.j: 創建については諸説あるが、祭神は古くから牛頭天王（およびそれに習合した素戔嗚尊）であったことは確実である。
sen.e: Although there are various stories about the early days, it is certain that Gozu Tenno (who shares similarities with Susanoo-no-mikoto) was the enshrined deity from early on.

Although there are various stories about the early days of the shrine, it is certain that Gozu-Tennou and Susanoo-no-mikoto (who shares similarities with Gozu-Tennou), were the enshrined deities from early on.
sen.cmt: 創建の後に、「当神社の」を加えた。習合した、にかかるのは素戔嗚尊。
sen.e: Although there are various stories about the early days of the shrine, it is certain that Gozu-Tennou and Susanoo-no-mikoto (who shares similarities with Gozu-Tennou), were the enshrined deities from early on.

sen.j: 古くからある神社であるが、延喜式神名帳には記されていない。
sen.e: Even though the shrine has been around since ancient times, it is not listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho.
sen.cmt: Engishiki Jinmyocho延喜式神名帳、表記裏づけとれず
sen.e: Even though the shrine has been around since ancient times, it is not listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho.
Even though the shrine has been around since ancient times, it is not listed in the Engishiki Jinmyocho.

sen.j: これは神仏習合の色あいが濃く延暦寺の支配を受けていたことから、神社ではなく寺とみなされていたためと見られるが、後の二十二社の一社にはなっており、神社としても見られていたことがわかる。
sen.e: This is because of the significant mixing of Shinto and Buddhism and the influence of Enryaku-ji temple, which is why it seems like it was seen as a temple and not a Shinto shrine; but since it later became one of the 22 Shrines, it is evident that it had come to be seen as a shrine.

This is because of the significant mixing of Shinto and Buddhism and the influence of Enryaku-ji temple, which is why the shrine seems to have been regarded as a temple and not a Shinto shrine; but since it later became one of the 22 Shrines, it is evident that it was also regarded as a shrine.
sen.cmt: みなす、にregarded を使った。
sen.e: This is because of the significant mixing of Shinto and Buddhism and the influence of Enryaku-ji temple, which is why the shrine seems to have been regarded as a temple and not a Shinto shrine; but since it later became one of the 22 Shrines, it is evident that it was also regarded as a shrine.

sen.j: 平安時代中期ごろから一帯の産土神として信仰されるようになり、朝廷からも篤い崇敬を受けた。
sen.e: Since about the middle of the Heian period it came to be worshiped as the deity of the local area, and enjoyed the reverence of the imperial court.
Since about the middle of the Heian period it came to be worshiped as the deity of the local area, and enjoyed the reverence of the imperial court.
Since about the middle of the Heian period it came to be worshiped as the deity of the local area, and enjoyed the reverence of the imperial court.

sen.j: 祇園祭は、貞観11年（869年）に各地で疫病が流行した際に神泉苑で行われた御霊会を起源とするもので、天禄元年（970年）ごろから当社の祭礼として毎年行われるようになった。
sen.e: The Gion Festival originated with a Goryoue that was held at Shinsenen in 869 when a plague had spread throughout the land, and came to be celebrated every year as this shrine's festival from around 970.
sen.cmt: 御霊会については以下の八坂神社のホームページ参照http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/yasaka/english/gion/index.html
sen.e: The Gion Festival originated with a Goryoue that was held at Shinsenen in 869 when a plague had spread throughout the land, and came to be celebrated every year as this shrine's festival from around 970.

The Gion Festival originated with a Goryoue that was held at Shinsenen in 869 when a plague had spread throughout the land, and came to be celebrated every year as this shrine's festival from around 970.

sen.j: 御同座 神大市比売命・佐美良比売命
sen.e: Godoza: Kamiooichihime-no-mikoto/Samirahime-no-mikoto
sen.cmt: セル50、51、53に記載されている「中御座」、「東御座」等はお神輿の名称。もう一つ「東若御座」があるが、これは子供神輿のこと。この「御同座」は中御座、東御座に一緒に乗っておられる神様のことだと思われる。 http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/yasaka/schedule/03.html http://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/raku/backnum/jul07_e/gion2007_e.html http://www.kyoto-nishiki.or.jp/event/mikoshi/mikoshi.htm http://www.geocities.co.jp/HeartLand-Suzuran/9371/mikosi.htm 佐美良比売命の表記、裏づけなし
sen.e: Godoza: Kamuooichihime-no-mikoto/Samirahime-no-mikoto
Godoza: Kamuooichihime-no-mikoto/Samirahime-no-mikoto

sen.cmt: 原文には多岐理毘売命、多岐理比売命とあるが、八坂神社の以下のホームページを見ると、美御前社の神様は市杵島比売命(イチキシマヒメノミコト）と、多岐理比売命(タギリヒメノミコト）、多岐津比売命(タギツヒメノミコト）とのこと。タギツヒメノミコトはTagitsuhime-no-mikotoと表記できるhttp://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/yasaka/shrine/utukushisha.html

sen.e: Otoshisha (Otoshi-no-kami, Chimatayashiro-no-kami)
sen.cmt: 以下の八坂神社のホームページを見ると、大年社の神様は巷社神とだけ書かれている。他のホームページには大年神と巷社神が記されているものもある。大年神はOtoshi-no-kami。http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/org/yasaka/shrine/08.htmlhttp://homepage.mac.com/y_aso/taisha/PhotoAlbum367.html巷社神→表記裏づけとれず
sen.e: Otoshisha (Otoshi-no-kami, Chimatayashiro-no-kami)

sen.j: 十社 -- 多賀社（伊邪那岐命）、熊野社（伊邪那美命）、白山社（菊理媛神）、愛宕社（伊邪那美命、火産霊命）、金峰社（金山彦命、イワナガヒメ）、春日社（天児屋根命、武甕槌神、斎主神、比売神）、香取社（経津主神）、諏訪社（タケミナカタ）、松尾社（大山咋命）、阿蘇社（健磐龍神、阿蘇都比咩命、速甕玉命）
sen.e: 10 Shrines - Tagahs (Izanagi-no-mikoto), Kumanosha (Izanami-no-mikoto), Hakusansha (Kukurihime-no-kami), Atagosha (Izanami-no-mikoto, Homusubi-no-mikoto) Kinposha (Kanayamahiko-no-mikoto, Iwanagahime), Kasugasha (Amanokoyane-no-mikoto, Takemikazuchi-no-kami, Iwainushi-no-kami, Hime-no-kami) Katorisha (Futsunushi-no-kami) Suwasha (Takeminakata), Matsuosha (Oyamakui-no-mikoto), Asosha (Takeiwatatsu-no-kami, Asotsuhime-no-mikoto, Hayamikatama-no-mikoto)
sen.cmt: 愛宕社の愛宕はセル31の地名だとオタギと読むが、神社の名称はあたごであると考えられる。
sen.e: 10 Shrines - Tagahs (Izanagi-no-mikoto), Kumanosha (Izanami-no-mikoto), Hakusansha (Kukurihime-no-kami), Atagosha (Izanami-no-mikoto, Homusubi-no-mikoto) Kinposha (Kanayamahiko-no-mikoto, Iwanagahime), Kasugasha (Amanokoyane-no-mikoto, Takemikazuchi-no-kami, Iwainushi-no-kami, Hime-no-kami) Katorisha (Futsunushi-no-kami) Suwasha (Takeminakata), Matsuosha (Oyamakui-no-mikoto), Asosha (Takeiwatatsu-no-kami, Asotsuhime-no-mikoto, Hayamikatama-no-mikoto)

sen.j: 五社 -- 八幡社（応神天皇）、竈神社（奥津日子神、奥津比売神）、風神社（天御柱命、国御柱命）、天神社（少彦名命）、水神社（高龗神、罔象女神）
sen.e: 5 Shrines - Hachimansha (Emperor Ojin), Kamadogamisha (Okitsuhiko-no-kami, Okitsuhime-no-kami), Fujinsha (Amenomihashira-no-mikoto, Kuninomihashira-no-mikoto), Tenjinsha (Sukunahikona-no-mikoto), Suijinsha (Takaokami-no-kami, Mitsuhanome-no-kami)

A Romon gate in the Kiritsuma-zukuri style (2-story building).

sen.j: 本殿 承応3年（1654年）‐一般の神社では別棟とする本殿と拝殿を1つの入母屋屋根で覆った独特の建築様式になり、「祇園造」と言われる。
sen.e: Main Hall: 1654 - Built in a distinctive style called Gion-zukuri, it combines the main hall and the worship hall (separate buildings at most shrines) under one Irimoya Yane roof.
Main Hall: 1654 - Built in a distinctive style called Gion-zukuri, it combines the main hall and the worship hall (separate buildings at most shrines) under one Irimoya Yane roof.
